elements.content: The combination of semiflexible terephthaloyl-bis-β-alaninate (TBbA2–) and metal ions at room temperature in aqueous solution results in the formation of five new compounds formulated as [Ca(TBbA)(H2O)3]·H2O (1), [Mn(TBbA)(H2O)2]·H2O (2), [Co(TBbA)(H2O)4]·2H2O (3), [Ni(TBbA)(H2O)4]·2H2O (4), and [Zn(TBbA)(H2O)4]·3H2O (5). Compounds 1 and 2 are two- and three-dimensional coordination polymers, respectively, possessing a 3,4L13 and sra topology. Compounds 3–5 are one-dimensional coordination polymers; 3 and 4 have a “plywood” conformation, and 5 has a zigzag conformation. The difference in the conformation of the three pseudopolymorphs 3–5 can be attributed to the different orientations of the ligand. Notably, in the reaction system of compounds 3 and 4, a second product can be obtained. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies show that these products have a structure similar to 5, indicating the existence of additional pseudopolymorphs, 3′ and 4′. Thermal and rehydration studies show that polymorphs 3′ and 4′ are transformed to 3 and 4, respectively, upon heating and rehydrating.

Compounds 1 and 2 are two- and three-dimensional coordination polymers, respectively, possessing a 3,4L13 and sra topology. Compounds 3-5 are one-dimensional coordination polymers; 3 and 4 have a "plywood" conformation, and 5 has a zigzag conformation. The difference in the conformation of the three pseudopolymorphs 3-5 can be attributed to the different orientations of the ligand. Notably, in the reaction system of compounds 3 and 4, a second product can be obtained. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies show that these products have a structure similar to 5, indicating the existence of additional pseudopolymorphs, 3' and 4'. Thermal and rehydration studies show that polymorphs 3' and 4' are transformed to 3 and 4, respectively, upon heating and rehydrating.

elements.content: The production of novel coordination polymers and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) using crystal engineering concepts has become increasingly popular in the past couple of decades. These versatile, nanoporous networks are easily tunable and possess a wide range of properties, making them ideal materials for applications in gas storage and separation, chemical and biological sensing, catalysis, magnetism, and luminescence. The properties of coordination polymers are controlled by their chemical composition and structure, which are easily manipulated by simply varying the reactants and reaction conditions. Much effort has been directed toward developing the ability to control the reactions so that the products can be engineered to have desired properties. From the crystal engineering and academic point of view, polymorphs and pseudopolymorphs have attracted significant interest in both scientific and industrial fields because different polymorphs and pseudopolymorphs show distinctive properties, such as stability, solubility, and bioavailability, and so forth, and it is of great interest to understand how to achieve their separation. In this work, we use the term “pseudopolymorphs” to represent crystal structures that differ only by hydration or solvation. Although the use of this word is still controversial, it is used widely in the literature.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The production of novel coordination polymers and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) using crystal engineering concepts has become increasingly popular in the past couple of decades. These versatile, nanoporous networks are easily tunable and possess a wide range of properties, making them ideal materials for applications in gas storage and separation, chemical and biological sensing, catalysis, magnetism, and luminescence. The properties of coordination polymers are controlled by their chemical composition and structure, which are easily manipulated by simply varying the reactants and reaction conditions. Much effort has been directed toward developing the ability to control the reactions so that the products can be engineered to have desired properties. From the crystal engineering and academic point of view, polymorphs and pseudopolymorphs have attracted significant interest in both scientific and industrial fields because different polymorphs and pseudopolymorphs show distinctive properties, such as stability, solubility, and bioavailability, and so forth, and it is of great interest to understand how to achieve their separation. In this work, we use the term "pseudopolymorphs" to represent crystal structures that differ only by hydration or solvation. Although the use of this word is still controversial, it is used widely in the literature.

elements.content: The compound 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (terephthalic acid, H2TPA; Scheme , left) and related compounds, such as trimesic acid, have been extensively investigated as ligands in the synthesis of coordination polymers and MOFs. We and others have focused on retaining the rigid aromatic skeleton of the terephthaloyl group and attaching to it flexible biomolecules, such as amino acids, for extra stabilization between the metal and the ligand. This idea is driven by (a) the investigation of the influence of the extension of the organic ligand’s flexible chains on the chemical reaction and (b) the synthesis of high-dimensional materials to construct nanoporous materials. Our initial project was accomplished using terephthaloyl-bis-glycine (H2TBG), which, unlike H2TPA, contains two amide groups and an extended carbon chain (Scheme , middle). The amide group, in addition to the carboxylic acid group, stabilizes the resulting complexes by providing hydrogen bonding to the metal centers. The coordination polymers obtained using this ligand have either a rare 2-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) structure with cds or pts topology, or a one-dimensional (1D) zigzag structure, depending on the metal radius.

elements.content: The next logical step in our study was to extend the flexible arms of the H2TBG ligand by one methylene group to investigate its influence on the structural motif of the final products. Hence, we utilized β-alanine instead of glycine to synthesize the ligand, terephthaloyl-bis-β-alanine, H2TBbA (Scheme , right). We report herein five new compounds formulated as [Ca(TBbA)(H2O)3]·H2O (1), [Mn(TBbA)(H2O)2]·H2O (2), [Co(TBbA)(H2O)4]·2H2O (3), [Ni(TBbA)(H2O)4]·2H2O (4), and [Zn(TBbA)(H2O)4]·3H2O (5).

Hence, we utilized β-alanine instead of glycine to synthesize the ligand, terephthaloyl-bis-β-alanine, H2TBbA (Scheme , right). elements.content: All chemicals and solvents used for synthesis were obtained from commercial sources and used as received without further purification. All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions. The 1H-NMR and 13C-NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AMX 500 MHz spectrometer. All spectra were recorded using commercially available d6-DMSO (Aldrich) of 99.6% isotopic purity or better and referenced to residual solvent. The elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out at the Institute of Nanotechnology, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology, using an Elementar Vario EL analyzer. Fourier transform IR spectra (4000 to 400 cm–1) were measured on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum GX spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr discs. Raman scattering measurements were performed using a 633-nm laser multichannel modular triple Raman system (JY-T6400) with confocal microscopy and a WITec microscope. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of 3 and its dehydrated and rehydrated analogues were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer UV/vis/NIR Lambda 900 Spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals and solvents used for synthesis were obtained from commercial sources and used as received without further purification. All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions. The 1H-NMR and 13C-NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AMX 500 MHz spectrometer. All spectra were recorded using commercially available d6-DMSO (Aldrich) of 99.6% isotopic purity or better and referenced to residual solvent. The elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out at the Institute of Nanotechnology, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology, using an Elementar Vario EL analyzer. Fourier transform IR spectra (4000 to 400 cm-1) were measured on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum GX spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr discs. Raman scattering measurements were performed using a 633-nm laser multichannel modular triple Raman system (JY-T6400) with confocal microscopy and a WITec microscope. UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of 3 and its dehydrated and rehydrated analogues were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer UV/vis/NIR Lambda 900 Spectrophotometer.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Terephthaloyl-bis-β-alanine (H2TBbA)

β-Alanine (7.48 g, 0.084 mol) and sodium hydroxide (6.00 g, 0.015 mol) were dissolved in water (50 mL) with stirring in a round-bottom flask in an ice bath. After the solution cooled to below 10 °C, a solution of terephthaloylchloride (8.12 g, 0.040 mol) dissolved in toluene (50 mL) was added dropwise. The reaction mixture stirred for 1 h, after which the aqueous phase was separated from the organic phase and collected. The aqueous phase was acidified with 35% hydrochloric acid until the pH was approximately 1. The white product was collected by vacuum filtration and dried in a vacuum oven overnight at 50 °C. Yield: 12.33 g, 100%. Anal. Calcd for C14H16N2O6 (found): C, 54.54 (54.22); H, 5.23 (5.20); N, 9.08 (8.80) %. 1H-NMR (ppm): 2.54 (q, 4 H, J = 10, 5, 10), 3.47 (q, 4 H, J = 5, 5, 10), 7.92 (s, 4 H), 12.31 (s, 1 H). 13C-NMR (ppm): 33.74, 33.65, 39.48, 127.12, 136.51, 165.58, 172.88. Selected IR data (KBr disk, cm-1): 3299 (s, b), 1703 (s), 1327 (s), 1540 (s), 1502 (s), 1476 (s), 1441 (s), 1425 (s), 1337 (s), 1306 (s), 1229 (s), 1203 (m), 1162 (m), 1129 (w), 1087 (m), 927 (s), 870 (s), 856 (m), 745 (m), 671 (s), 537 (w), 525 (w), 425 (m).

elements.content: The same procedure was followed for the preparation of all compounds, so only the synthesis of 1 is described in detail. H2TBbA (152 mg, 0.500 mol) and potassium carbonate (69 mg, 0.500 mol) were dissolved in water (25 mL) with stirring. Ca(NO3)2 ·3H2O (118 mg, 0.500 mol) was added to the solution. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 5 min, remaining clear and colorless, and was then filtered and left undisturbed at room temperature. Slow evaporation of the solvent yielded colorless, block-shaped crystals after 1 day. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with water, and dried in a vacuum oven overnight at 50 °C. Yield: 98 mg, 47% based on Ca. Anal. Calcd for C14H22CaN2O10 (found): C, 40.19 (40.38); H, 5.30 (5.41); N, 6.70 (6.75) %. Selected IR data (KBr disk, cm–1): 3329 (b), 1633 (s), 1565 (s), 1513 (m), 1492 (m), 1418 (s), 1364 (m), 1334 (m), 1321 (m), 1304 (m), 1288 (m), 1260 (m), 1209 (m), 1171 (w), 1154 (w), 1081 (w), 1006 (w), 946 (w), 867 (m), 721 (s), 669 (s), 528 (m), 501 (m), 484 (m), 445 (w).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves were measured using a Netzsch STA 409C Thermal Analyzer under nitrogen flow (30 mL/min) at a scan rate of 5 °C/min from 23 to 800 °C with a sample size around 15 mg. The reversibility of water loss of compounds 3 and 4 was checked by heating a small sample of each in a vacuum oven at 50 °C overnight. The dehydrated product was characterized by IR, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV/vis DRS, and elemental analysis. The dehydrated product was then rehydrated by suspending the sample in water. The dehydration/rehydration procedure was repeated on the same sample and characterized by IR to confirm that the water loss is reversible.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Studies

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves were measured using a Netzsch STA 409C Thermal Analyzer under nitrogen flow (30 mL/min) at a scan rate of 5 °C/min from 23 to 800 °C with a sample size around 15 mg. The reversibility of water loss of compounds 3 and 4 was checked by heating a small sample of each in a vacuum oven at 50 °C overnight. The dehydrated product was characterized by IR, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV/vis DRS, and elemental analysis. The dehydrated product was then rehydrated by suspending the sample in water. The dehydration/rehydration procedure was repeated on the same sample and characterized by IR to confirm that the water loss is reversible.

elements.content: Data for 1–5 were collected at 180 K on a Stoe IPDS II area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo–Kα radiation. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using XPREP in SHELXTL. The structures were solved using direct methods, followed by a full-matrix least-squares refinement against F 2 (all data) using SHELXTL. Anisotropic refinement was used for all ordered non-hydrogen atoms; organic hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions, while coordinates of hydroxo hydrogen and amine hydrogen atoms were refined. The crystallographic and structure refinement data for all compounds are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Determination

Data for 1-5 were collected at 180 K on a Stoe IPDS II area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using XPREP in SHELXTL. The structures were solved using direct methods, followed by a full-matrix least-squares refinement against F 2 (all data) using SHELXTL. Anisotropic refinement was used for all ordered non-hydrogen atoms; organic hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions, while coordinates of hydroxo hydrogen and amine hydrogen atoms were refined. The crystallographic and structure refinement data for all compounds are given in Table .

Compounds 1–5 were prepared by the reaction of the H2TBbA, potassium carbonate, and a metal salt. Note that the counterion of the metal salts for each synthesis varied (see Experimental Section for details). Isomorphous compounds were obtained using sodium carbonate, lithium hydroxide, or sodium hydroxide instead of potassium carbonate. Using salts with different counterions, including nitrate, chloride, acetate, and sulfate, did not result in any change to the final products. In addition, reactions were carried out both at room temperature and under reflux as well as with different metal-to-ligand ratios (3:1 to 1:3), and all variations resulted in the same isomorphous products. The crystal structures of the products from all reaction conditions were matched to the crystals reported herein by comparing their powder XRD patterns, unit cells, and IR spectra. Finally, it should be noted that all compounds are stable in air.
elements.clean_text:
Results

Synthesis

Compounds 1-5 were prepared by the reaction of the H2TBbA, potassium carbonate, and a metal salt. Note that the counterion of the metal salts for each synthesis varied (see Experimental Section for details). Isomorphous compounds were obtained using sodium carbonate, lithium hydroxide, or sodium hydroxide instead of potassium carbonate. Using salts with different counterions, including nitrate, chloride, acetate, and sulfate, did not result in any change to the final products. In addition, reactions were carried out both at room temperature and under reflux as well as with different metal-to-ligand ratios (3:1 to 1:3), and all variations resulted in the same isomorphous products. The crystal structures of the products from all reaction conditions were matched to the crystals reported herein by comparing their powder XRD patterns, unit cells, and IR spectra. Finally, it should be noted that all compounds are stable in air.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the P21/n space group and has four molecules in the asymmetric unit. The coordination sphere of the metal centers and ligand bonding is shown in Figure . Each metal center has distorted pentagonal bipyramidal coordination geometry with coordination to three water molecules (O7, O8, O9) and one monodentate oxygen (O3) of an amide group, one monodentate carboxylate group (O2), and one bidentate carboxylate (O4 and O5) of three different ligands. The mean M–O bond distance is 2.42 Å, which is the longest M–O distance observed in this study. The vertical axis on each metal center consists of coordination to a water molecule and the oxygen of the amide group in the ligand. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in , and hydrogen bonding distances are given in . Note that the angles between the vertical axis and the equatorial species are roughly 92°, except for the angles between the vertical axis and the oxygen atoms of the bidentate ligand. These two bonds are significantly out of the horizontal plane, with angles of 100° and 78°.

The mean M-O bond distance is 2.42 Å, which is the longest M-O distance observed in this study. The vertical axis on each metal center consists of coordination to a water molecule and the oxygen of the amide group in the ligand. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in , and hydrogen bonding distances are given in . Note that the angles between the vertical axis and the equatorial species are roughly 92°, except for the angles between the vertical axis and the oxygen atoms of the bidentate ligand. These two bonds are significantly out of the horizontal plane, with angles of 100° and 78°.

elements.content: There are two chemically independent bridging organic ligands within the asymmetric unit of 1. One of these ligands coordinates to two different metal centers via bidentate chelation of the ligand’s carboxylate groups (Scheme , mode A). For the second ligand type, the two carboxylate groups of the ligand coordinate to one metal center each, and the oxygen atoms of the amide bonds ligate to one metal center each; thus, such ligands are coordinated to four different metal centers in a monodentate fashion (Scheme , mode B).

elements.content: The chains of the ligands are arranged in a syn-anti conformation about the benzene ring. The crystal is constructed from planes parallel to the bc plane (Figure ) that are bridged by coordination between monodentate carboxylates of the ligand and metal centers. This bonding motif, along with hydrogen bonding of lattice water molecules, yields an open, two-dimensional (2D) structure.

elements.content: Infinite 2D planes, observed from the bc plane, that form the 2D network of compound 1. Color code: Ca green, O red, N blue, C gray.
elements.clean_text: 2  Infinite 2D planes, observed from the bc plane, that form the 2D network of compound 1. Color code: Ca green, O red, N blue, C gray.

elements.content: The topological representation of the 2D network found in 1 is shown in Figure . A binodal (3,4) net is constructed by considering each Ca(II) center (Figure , green) and each tetradentate ligand (Figure , mauve) as a node. Each calcium node is connected to two ligand nodes and one calcium node, while each ligand node is connected to four calcium nodes. Topological analysis of this net reveals that it possesses 3,4L13 topology. A survey in the TOPOS database shows that there are 66 examples of 3,4L13 topology, of which there are 32 containing cadmium, 19 zinc, 8 silver and 7 copper; thus, compound 1 is the first compound containing calcium to have this topology.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the P21/c space group and has four molecules in the asymmetric unit. The coordination sphere of the metal centers and ligand bonding is shown in Figure . In the unit cell, there are four lattice water molecules that are connected to the network by four hydrogen bonds each as well as 16 aqua ligands. Each metal center has distorted octahedral coordination geometry with coordination to two water molecules (one equatorial, O8, and one axial, O7), three monodentate carboxylates of three different ligands (O1, O5, and O6) and one oxygen of an amide group of a fourth ligand (O3). The mean M–O distance is 2.17 Å, which is shorter than the mean M–O length observed in 1. The vertical axis on each metal consists of coordination to a water molecule and the oxygen of the amide group in the ligand. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in , and hydrogen bonding distances are given in . Note that the equatorial species lay 1.31–6.82° above and below the horizontal plane. Contrary to compound 1, only one coordination mode of ligand is found in 2: each ligand is ligated to four different metal centers via one amide oxygen atom O(3) and to three oxygen atoms of two terminal carboxylate groups (Scheme , mode C).

elements.content: The chains of the ligands are arranged in a syn-anti conformation about the benzene ring, as observed in 1. Figure shows the packing of 2 from the perspective of the ac plane. 2D planes are formed by ligands coordinating to Mn(II) centers through the carboxylate oxygen atoms parallel to the direction of the ac plane. These layers are interconnected through the Mn(II) centers via hydrogen bonding of the amide oxygen atom, O(3), to form a 3D structure.

elements.content: The complicated packing of compound 2 can be easily analyzed topologically if each manganese center and each organic ligand is considered a node. Using the TOPOS software, the structure of 2 can be rationalized as a binodal network containing two four-connected nodes. The topological evaluation is shown in Figure , and analysis of this net reveals that it possesses sra topology. A survey in the TOPOS database shows another 121 coordination polymers with similar topology.

elements.content: Compound 4 produces a crystalline material from which we were unable to isolate an appropriate crystal for single X-ray analysis; however, the comparison of powder XRD studies (ESI), IR spectra, and elemental analyses indicate that compounds 3 and 4 are isostructural, so only 3 will be discussed here in detail. Compound 3 crystallizes in the P21/c space group and has two molecules in the asymmetric unit. The coordination sphere of the metal centers and ligand bonding is shown in Figure . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in , and hydrogen bonding distances are given in . In the unit cell there are four lattice water molecules that are connected to the network by four hydrogen bonds each as well as six aqua ligands (). Each metal center has octahedral coordination geometry with coordination to four water molecules in the equatorial positions (O1 and O4) and two monodentate carboxylate groups in the axial positions (O5). The mean M–O distance is 2.09 Å, which is less than that in compounds 1 and 2. Note that the angle between the axial-coordinated species through the metal center is 180°, and the equatorial species are all less than 2.5° out of the horizontal plane. Each ligand coordinates to two different metal centers via an oxygen atom of the two terminal carboxylate groups, both of which show monodentate chelation (Scheme , mode D).

elements.content: As in compounds 1 and 2, the chains of the ligands in compounds 3 and 4 are arranged in a syn-anti conformation about the benzene ring. From the perspective of the ab plane, the structure of 3 consists of 1D rows organized into planes, such that each plane consists of parallel rows linked to each other through hydrogen bonding, forming a 2D layer that extends along the bisections of the ac planes (Figure , top). The unusual feature of 3 is that two 1D polymeric chains span in two different directions, giving rise to a plywood-like structure (Figure , bottom). These chains lie parallel within each layer but nonparallel in alternate layers. The two different layers are inclined at an angle of 50.71°, resulting in hydrogen-bonded entanglement, which is well-known as a p–p polycatenation motif, according to the classification made by Ciani, et al. Notably, the 2D layers interact with each other only through hydrogen bonding and not stacking interactions.

These chains lie parallel within each layer but nonparallel in alternate layers. The two different layers are inclined at an angle of 50.71°, resulting in hydrogen-bonded entanglement, which is well-known as a p-p polycatenation motif, according to the classification made by Ciani, et al. Notably, the 2D layers interact with each other only through hydrogen bonding and not stacking interactions.

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in the P1̅ space group and has two molecules in the asymmetric unit. The coordination sphere of the zinc centers and ligand bonding is shown in Figure . In the unit cell, there are six lattice water molecules that are connected to the network by four hydrogen bonds each as well as eight aqua ligands. Each metal center has octahedral geometry with coordination to four water molecules occupying the equatorial positions (O7 and O8) and two monodentate carboxylates of two different ligands occupying the axial positions (O1). The mean M–O distance is 2.10 Å, which is similar to that observed in compounds 3 and 4. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in , and hydrogen bonding distances are given in . Note that the equatorial species are all less than 2.0° out of the horizontal plane. The angle between equatorial species is 93.21 and 86.79°. Each ligand coordinates to two different metal centers via an oxygen atom of the two terminal carboxylate groups, both of which are monodentate (Scheme , mode E).

elements.content: Contrary to compounds 1–4, the chains of the ligands in compound 5 are arranged in a syn-syn conformation about the benzene ring. The crystal is constructed from 1D chains running through the ac plane (Figure , bottom). These are aligned antiparallel, and metal centers are separated by ligands or lattice water molecules. The 1D coordination polymers are connected only through hydrogen bonding. It is worth stating that a given 1D chain is held to two adjacent chains possessing an inverse conformation to give layers with ABABAB conformation. Lattice water molecules occupy the space between planes; thus, the structure is extended to three dimensions through hydrogen bonds of the lattice water molecules ().

elements.content: The powder XRD patterns of the bulk material of compounds 1, 2, and 5 (, respectively) show that the previously crystallographically described compounds are the only products of these reactions. However, the powder XRD patterns of the bulk material of compounds 3 and 4 indicate that neither material is phase pure (Figure ). For that reason, several reactions were performed to authenticate the nature of this impurity. In a given reaction for 3, big, pink, plate-like crystals form after 1 h and have been identified as having the crystal structure described above. However, upon further crystallization, small crystals, which are not suitable for single X-ray studies, also formed. The powder XRD pattern of the bulk material presented in Figure corresponds to a mixture of both products. A useful conclusion regarding the nature of the impurity seen in the powder pattern of the bulk material of 3 can be drawn from comparing the measured pattern along with the simulated powder patterns of 3 and 5 (Figure ). Efforts to record the powder XRD pattern of the second crystalline product in the synthesis of 3 would be helpful for authentication purposes; however, this was not successful because a similar pattern to the one shown in Figure 10 was recorded in all of our efforts. Comparing the patterns shown in Figure , one can see that several peaks (highlighted as blue bars) of the impurity in the pattern correspond to an analogue of compound 3 that possesses a structure similar to 5. A comparison of the molecular formulas of 3 and 5, indicates that these two compounds can be considered pseudopolymorphs; we suggest that the second product that is formed in the reaction of 3 upon further crystallization, is compound 3′ and is isostructural to 5.

The powder XRD patterns of the bulk material of compounds 1, 2, and 5 (, respectively) show that the previously crystallographically described compounds are the only products of these reactions. However, the powder XRD patterns of the bulk material of compounds 3 and 4 indicate that neither material is phase pure (Figure ). For that reason, several reactions were performed to authenticate the nature of this impurity. In a given reaction for 3, big, pink, plate-like crystals form after 1 h and have been identified as having the crystal structure described above. However, upon further crystallization, small crystals, which are not suitable for single X-ray studies, also formed. The powder XRD pattern of the bulk material presented in Figure  corresponds to a mixture of both products. A useful conclusion regarding the nature of the impurity seen in the powder pattern of the bulk material of 3 can be drawn from comparing the measured pattern along with the simulated powder patterns of 3 and 5 (Figure ). Efforts to record the powder XRD pattern of the second crystalline product in the synthesis of 3 would be helpful for authentication purposes; however, this was not successful because a similar pattern to the one shown in Figure 10 was recorded in all of our efforts. Comparing the patterns shown in Figure , one can see that several peaks (highlighted as blue bars) of the impurity in the pattern correspond to an analogue of compound 3 that possesses a structure similar to 5. A comparison of the molecular formulas of 3 and 5, indicates that these two compounds can be considered pseudopolymorphs; we suggest that the second product that is formed in the reaction of 3 upon further crystallization, is compound 3' and is isostructural to 5.

elements.content: Interestingly, by heating some of the bulk material of compounds 3 and 3′, the removal of the lattice and ligated water molecules is successful (Figure ). Upon removal of the water molecules, cobalt adopts tetrahedral geometry (), indicating that the heated product of 3 retains its dimensionality and does not collapse (Figure ). When a rehydration procedure is followed, cobalt readopts an octahedral geometry (). The powder XRD pattern and the IR spectrum of the rehydrated product indicate that only the major pseudopolymorph of 3 is reformed. The same dehydration/rehydration procedure was repeated multiple times on compound 3, and only the major pseudopolymorph was reformed each time. A similar behavior is also observed for compound 4 (). It is worth noting that when a similar dehydration/rehydration procedure is performed on pseudopolymorph 5, the rehydrated product retains the initial structure of compound 5.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on compounds 1–3 and 5 (), including the dehydrated analogue for compound 3 (Figure ). All water was successfully removed from the original compound 3, as indicated by the lack of a mass loss around 100 °C in the curve of the dehydrated analogue of 3 (Figure ). At 290 °C for 3 and 281 °C for the dehydrated analogue of 3, decomposition begins, leaving the metal oxide as the final residue.

TGA Studies

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on compounds 1-3 and 5 (), including the dehydrated analogue for compound 3 (Figure ). All water was successfully removed from the original compound 3, as indicated by the lack of a mass loss around 100 °C in the curve of the dehydrated analogue of 3 (Figure ). At 290 °C for 3 and 281 °C for the dehydrated analogue of 3, decomposition begins, leaving the metal oxide as the final residue.

elements.content: The first comment regarding the aforementioned structures concerns the different conformations of 3, 4, and 5. There is significant discussion in the literature about the meaning and use of the term, pseudopolymorph; however, it is not our intention to address this issue in this paper. A comparison of the molecular formulas, the coordination behavior of the ligand, and the coordination geometry of the metal centers in compounds 3–5 indicate that these results can be best described by adopting the term pseudopolymorph. A better insight into the hydrogen bonding motif of the 1D chains in 3 and 5 shows that these interact via a similar motif; therefore, we might suggest that the ligated and lattice water molecules in 3 and 5 do not play an important role in the different conformation of the pseudopolymorphs.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The first comment regarding the aforementioned structures concerns the different conformations of 3, 4, and 5. There is significant discussion in the literature about the meaning and use of the term, pseudopolymorph; however, it is not our intention to address this issue in this paper. A comparison of the molecular formulas, the coordination behavior of the ligand, and the coordination geometry of the metal centers in compounds 3-5 indicate that these results can be best described by adopting the term pseudopolymorph. A better insight into the hydrogen bonding motif of the 1D chains in 3 and 5 shows that these interact via a similar motif; therefore, we might suggest that the ligated and lattice water molecules in 3 and 5 do not play an important role in the different conformation of the pseudopolymorphs.

elements.content: The second general remark for compounds 1–5, in comparison with our previous study with terephthaloyl-bis-glycine (H2TBG), is the fact that the increased flexibility of the side chain does not allow any stacking interaction to stabilize the frameworks. In all of the aforementioned cases, the distances between the centroids of the aromatic rings are more than 4.0 Å and have a high offset; therefore, hydrogen bonding between the compounds and the lattice water molecules is the only interaction that enhances the stability of those frameworks.

A better understanding of the influence of the increased length of the organic ligand’s side chain on the shape of the final motif can be gained by comparing the results obtained for the manganese, cobalt, and zinc complexes of the previous study with the H2TBG ligand to the results in this paper (Table ). In the H2TBG study, synthetic procedures similar to those reported herein were followed, and the organic ligand adopted bidentate (manganese and cobalt) and bis-chelating (zinc) coordination behavior and a syn-anti conformation for all compounds. The manganese and zinc analogues resulted in 1D chains, with manganese and zinc adopting octahedral and pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, respectively. Interestingly, in the cobalt compound, each cobalt center possesses octahedral geometry, resulting in a 3D structure with cds topology. This is largely due to the presence of water bridges. In the results reported herein, the metal centers of compounds 2–5 possess octahedral geometry. Compound 2 possesses a 3D structure with sra topology, with the ligand bonding to four Mn(II) centers; compounds 3 and 4 form 1D chains in a “plywood” conformation, and, surprisingly, the ligand adopts a different conformation in compound 5, resulting in 1D zigzag chains.

elements.content: It is invalid to suppose that the closed shell orbitals in 5 influence the syn-syn conformation of the organic ligands because a similar pseudopolymorph can be found for 3 and 4. There is also the fact that the dehydration/rehydration procedure performed on compounds 3 and 4 results in pseudopolymorphs with structures similar to 5, suggesting that the structure of 5 is more stable. By considering this in conjunction with the results shown in Table , we may suggest that the difference in the conformation of the ligand in 5 arises because the ligand does not prefer to chelate to each zinc center. Each zinc center adopts octahedral instead of pentagonal bipyramidal geometry; therefore, the freedom that is introduced into the system via the organic ligand results in a different ligand conformation for 5.

elements.content: Finally, an interesting observation regarding the dimensionality of the final product can be made from the comparison of compounds 1 and 2. Although Ca(II) has a larger radius than Mn(II) and is more likely to ligate to amide oxygen atoms, compound 1 has a 2D structure whereas compound 2 is 3D. This indicates that larger ionic radii of the central metals do not necessarily result in higher-dimensional motifs.

elements.content: A series of coordination polymers derived from the combination of the semiflexible terephthaloyl-bis-β-alaninate (TBbA2–) ligand and metal ions at room temperature in aqueous solution have been synthesized and characterized. The structural differences among compounds 1–5 highlight the effect of the metal center on their framework construction. The increased carbon chain length is shown in this study to dramatically affect the way in which the ligand coordinates to the metal centers, as exemplified, for instance, by the absence of stacking interactions found in the previous studies. Compounds 1 and 2 are 2D and 3D coordination polymers, respectively, possessing a 3,4L13 and sra topology, while compounds 3–5 can be considered pseudopolymorphs of 1D coordination polymers with “plywood” conformation for 3–4 and zigzag conformation for 5. The difference in the conformation of the three pseudopolymorphs 3–5 can be attributed to the different orientation of the ligand. Notably, in the reaction system of compounds 3 and 4, a second product can be obtained. Powder XRD studies show that it represents a structure similar to 5, indicating the existence of additional pseudopolymorphs, 3′ and 4′. Thermal and rehydration studies show that polymorphs 3′ and 4′ are transformed into 3 and 4, respectively, upon heating and rehydrating. Additional investigations concerning the coordination behavior of this ligand are in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A series of coordination polymers derived from the combination of the semiflexible terephthaloyl-bis-β-alaninate (TBbA2-) ligand and metal ions at room temperature in aqueous solution have been synthesized and characterized. The structural differences among compounds 1-5 highlight the effect of the metal center on their framework construction. The increased carbon chain length is shown in this study to dramatically affect the way in which the ligand coordinates to the metal centers, as exemplified, for instance, by the absence of stacking interactions found in the previous studies. Compounds 1 and 2 are 2D and 3D coordination polymers, respectively, possessing a 3,4L13 and sra topology, while compounds 3-5 can be considered pseudopolymorphs of 1D coordination polymers with "plywood" conformation for 3-4 and zigzag conformation for 5. The difference in the conformation of the three pseudopolymorphs 3-5 can be attributed to the different orientation of the ligand. Notably, in the reaction system of compounds 3 and 4, a second product can be obtained. Powder XRD studies show that it represents a structure similar to 5, indicating the existence of additional pseudopolymorphs, 3' and 4'. Thermal and rehydration studies show that polymorphs 3' and 4' are transformed into 3 and 4, respectively, upon heating and rehydrating. Additional investigations concerning the coordination behavior of this ligand are in progress.

β-Alanine (7.48 g, 0.084 mol) and sodium hydroxide (6.00 g, 0.015 mol) were dissolved in water (50 mL) with stirring in a round-bottom flask in an ice bath. After the solution cooled to below 10 °C, a solution of terephthaloylchloride (8.12 g, 0.040 mol) dissolved in toluene (50 mL) was added dropwise. The reaction mixture stirred for 1 h, after which the aqueous phase was separated from the organic phase and collected. The aqueous phase was acidified with 35% hydrochloric acid until the pH was approximately 1. The white product was collected by vacuum filtration and dried in a vacuum oven overnight at 50 °C. Yield: 12.33 g, 100%. Anal. Calcd for C14H16N2O6 (found): C, 54.54 (54.22); H, 5.23 (5.20); N, 9.08 (8.80) %. 1H-NMR (ppm): 2.54 (q, 4 H, J = 10, 5, 10), 3.47 (q, 4 H, J = 5, 5, 10), 7.92 (s, 4 H), 12.31 (s, 1 H). 13C-NMR (ppm): 33.74, 33.65, 39.48, 127.12, 136.51, 165.58, 172.88. Selected IR data (KBr disk, cm–1): 3299 (s, b), 1703 (s), 1327 (s), 1540 (s), 1502 (s), 1476 (s), 1441 (s), 1425 (s), 1337 (s), 1306 (s), 1229 (s), 1203 (m), 1162 (m), 1129 (w), 1087 (m), 927 (s), 870 (s), 856 (m), 745 (m), 671 (s), 537 (w), 525 (w), 425 (m).

Synthesis of [Ca(TBbA)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

The same procedure was followed for the preparation of all compounds, so only the synthesis of 1 is described in detail. H2TBbA (152 mg, 0.500 mol) and potassium carbonate (69 mg, 0.500 mol) were dissolved in water (25 mL) with stirring. Ca(NO3)2 ·3H2O (118 mg, 0.500 mol) was added to the solution. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 5 min, remaining clear and colorless, and was then filtered and left undisturbed at room temperature. Slow evaporation of the solvent yielded colorless, block-shaped crystals after 1 day. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with water, and dried in a vacuum oven overnight at 50 °C. Yield: 98 mg, 47% based on Ca. Anal. Calcd for C14H22CaN2O10 (found): C, 40.19 (40.38); H, 5.30 (5.41); N, 6.70 (6.75) %. Selected IR data (KBr disk, cm–1): 3329 (b), 1633 (s), 1565 (s), 1513 (m), 1492 (m), 1418 (s), 1364 (m), 1334 (m), 1321 (m), 1304 (m), 1288 (m), 1260 (m), 1209 (m), 1171 (w), 1154 (w), 1081 (w), 1006 (w), 946 (w), 867 (m), 721 (s), 669 (s), 528 (m), 501 (m), 484 (m), 445 (w).

Synthesis of [Mn(TBbA)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

The metal salt used was Mn(OAc)2 ·4H2O. The product was obtained as colorless needles. Yield: 69 mg, 33% based on Mn. Anal. Calcd for C14H20MnN2O9 (found): C, 40.49 (40.63); H, 4.86 (4.27); N, 6.74 (6.73) %. Selected IR data (KBr disk, cm–1): 3379 (s, b), 1629 (m), 1556 (s), 1506 (m), 1445 (m), 1428 (m), 1408 (m), 1374 (w), 1357 (w), 1327 (m), 1309 (w), 1262 (m), 1212 (w), 1161 (w), 1128 (w), 1078 (w), 1029 (w), 1006 (w), 867 (m), 852 (m), 768 (w), 722 (m), 692 (m), 679 (m), 615 (m), 542 (m), 484 (m).

Synthesis of [Co(TBbA)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

Synthesis of Terephthaloyl-bis-β-alanine (H2TBbA)

β-Alanine (7.48 g, 0.084 mol) and sodium hydroxide (6.00 g, 0.015 mol) were dissolved in water (50 mL) with stirring in a round-bottom flask in an ice bath. After the solution cooled to below 10 °C, a solution of terephthaloylchloride (8.12 g, 0.040 mol) dissolved in toluene (50 mL) was added dropwise. The reaction mixture stirred for 1 h, after which the aqueous phase was separated from the organic phase and collected. The aqueous phase was acidified with 35% hydrochloric acid until the pH was approximately 1. The white product was collected by vacuum filtration and dried in a vacuum oven overnight at 50 °C. Yield: 12.33 g, 100%. Anal. Calcd for C14H16N2O6 (found): C, 54.54 (54.22); H, 5.23 (5.20); N, 9.08 (8.80) %. 1H-NMR (ppm): 2.54 (q, 4 H, J = 10, 5, 10), 3.47 (q, 4 H, J = 5, 5, 10), 7.92 (s, 4 H), 12.31 (s, 1 H). 13C-NMR (ppm): 33.74, 33.65, 39.48, 127.12, 136.51, 165.58, 172.88. Selected IR data (KBr disk, cm-1): 3299 (s, b), 1703 (s), 1327 (s), 1540 (s), 1502 (s), 1476 (s), 1441 (s), 1425 (s), 1337 (s), 1306 (s), 1229 (s), 1203 (m), 1162 (m), 1129 (w), 1087 (m), 927 (s), 870 (s), 856 (m), 745 (m), 671 (s), 537 (w), 525 (w), 425 (m).

Synthesis of [Ca(TBbA)(H2O)3]⋅H2O (1)

The same procedure was followed for the preparation of all compounds, so only the synthesis of 1 is described in detail. H2TBbA (152 mg, 0.500 mol) and potassium carbonate (69 mg, 0.500 mol) were dissolved in water (25 mL) with stirring. Ca(NO3)2 ⋅3H2O (118 mg, 0.500 mol) was added to the solution. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 5 min, remaining clear and colorless, and was then filtered and left undisturbed at room temperature. Slow evaporation of the solvent yielded colorless, block-shaped crystals after 1 day. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with water, and dried in a vacuum oven overnight at 50 °C. Yield: 98 mg, 47% based on Ca. Anal. Calcd for C14H22CaN2O10 (found): C, 40.19 (40.38); H, 5.30 (5.41); N, 6.70 (6.75) %.
